entry.title: Re: Functional Location Structure Indicator Issue while d...
entry.content:
Possible Causes of Structure Indicator Mismatches are
Missing or Incorrect Structure Indicator Configuration. The structure indicator must be predefined in Customizing before loading data. If the indicator used in the template doesn't match what's configured in the system (edit mask, hierarchy levels), SAP may default to a different one or reject the format.
Even if the hierarchy levels look fine, the edit mask (which controls allowed characters and grouping) might differ. For example, a mask like AA-AA-AA vs. AAA-AA-AA will cause mismatches.
Structure indicators are managed at the client level, so if you're working across systems or clients, the indicator might not exist or be different in the target system.
If you're using reference functional locations, the system may apply the structure indicator from the reference instead of the one in your template.
Sometimes the field mapping in the Migration Cockpit doesn‚Äôt correctly link the structure indicator field to the backend table, especially if custom fields or enhancements are involved.

What You Can Do
- Double-check the structure indicator configuration in SPRO > Plant Maintenance and Customer Service > Master Data > Technical Objects > Functional Locations > Create Structure Indicator. There
- Verify that the edit mask and hierarchy levels match exactly between the template and system config.
- Ensure the structure indicator exists and is active in the target system/client.
- If needed, manually create or adjust the structure indicator before reloading the data.

entry.title: Exploring the Fundamentals of Setting up and Running SAP Commerce Cloud in a B2B Environment
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to share some exciting news for SAP Commerce Cloud business users, consultants, and sales professionals! A brand-new learning journey has arrived on learning.sap.com:

Exploring the Fundamentals of Setting up and Running SAP Commerce Cloud in a B2B Environment

What's in it for you?

  • Business Users: Discover how SAP Commerce Cloud can streamline your B2B operations, enhance customer experiences, and drive sales growth. Learn key functionalities and explore practical applications for your specific business needs.
  • Consultants: Expand your expertise and gain a competitive edge by mastering the intricacies of SAP Commerce Cloud for B2B implementations. This learning journey will equip you with the knowledge and skills to deliver successful client projects.
  • Sales Professionals: Strengthen your sales pitches and confidently articulate the value proposition of SAP Commerce Cloud for B2B customers. Understand the platform's capabilities and effectively address client needs.

After completing this learning journey, the learner will be able to:

  • Construct the merchant sales organization including users and spend thresholds.
  • Reproduce the customer purchasing organization in the My Company Section of SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Employ the storefront order process, including cart assembly, checkout, approval and quote negotiations. 
  • Describe that integrated buying is supported in SAP Commerce Cloud via Punchout support.

The learning journey consists of 4 units:

  • Setting up the Merchant Organization and Customer Specific Thresholds:This unit teaches you how to replicate a sales organization within SAP Commerce Cloud, connect it to various customer purchasing organizations, and configure credit limits and quote negotiation thresholds.
     
  • Managing the Customer Sales Organization in SAP Commerce Cloud: This unit teaches you how to set up a customer's purchasing structure within SAP Commerce Cloud, including configuring user roles and purchase limits, and managing cost centers and budgets.
  • Purchasing and Selling on the SAP Commerce Cloud B2B Storefront: This unit covers the B2B storefront ordering process in SAP Commerce Cloud, from exploring ordering options and negotiating quotes to navigating the checkout process and managing order approvals.
  • Pairing SAP Commerce Cloud with Procurement Systems using Punchout: This unit explains how SAP Commerce Cloud supports integrated buying through PunchOut functionality.

The learning journey contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The Learning Journey is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this learning journey and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: Re: Post Depreciation on last period only
entry.content: Solely at asset class level, it cannot be controlled. However, in your asset class, assign depreciation key - Z7512 as a default. So, while Asset Class helps default the logic, the actual Period 12-only behavior must be embedded in the depreciation key and depreciation area setup.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series Finale: Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead
entry.content:
After eight powerful sessions, the ‚ÄúArchitecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Journey ‚Äì From Data to Intelligence‚Äù webinar series came to a close on July 25th with an inspiring final chapter: ‚ÄúSAP BDC Series Wrap-Up ‚Äì Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead.‚Äù

As someone deeply involved in enterprise architecture at SAP, I didn‚Äôt just watch this series as an internal stakeholder. I experienced it like many of you ‚Äî trying to understand how we move forward, how we transform data from. a static asset into a living, breathing foundation for innovation. This wasn‚Äôt just about technology. It was about possibility.   This closing session wasn‚Äôt just the end of a series ‚Äî it felt like a milestone in a journey many of us have been walking together. 

Moderated by Paul Kurchina and joined by visionary voices like Prakash Nanduri, Timo Elliott, Ralph Richter, and Gaurish Dessai, the session offered far more than a recap. It brought clarity on where we are ‚Äî and where we‚Äôre heading next.

After eight weeks of listening, learning, questioning, and connecting, one thing is clear: Business Data Cloud is no longer just a concept. It‚Äôs something we‚Äôre actively building, together.

So instead of a simple summary, I want to share a few personal reflections ‚Äî the moments that stayed with me, the insights that truly resonated, and the themes I believe will shape the next chapter in our data journey.

Why SAP Business Data Cloud?

When Prakash Nanduri spoke, it was more than a product overview ‚Äî it was a mission statement. Prakash, a long-time entrepreneur and now back at SAP, shared how BDC isn‚Äôt just another SAP initiative. It‚Äôs about transforming the core of how businesses use data.

‚ÄúSAP has automated business processes for 50 years,‚Äù Prakash said. ‚ÄúNow it‚Äôs time to make the data from those processes the engine for the next generation of intelligence.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what BDC is really about: The ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù Behind BDC:

  1. Harmonizing SAP and non-SAP data so that AI, analytics, planning, and predictive models have a clean, reliable foundation.
  2. Creating consistent, connected processes across SAP applications ‚Äî from S/4HANA to Ariba, SuccessFactors, and more.

Five Guiding Principles of SAP Business Data Cloud

What makes BDC different? It‚Äôs not just a product. It‚Äôs a strategy, rooted in five key principles:

  1. Persona-Centric Design: BDC is built for specific users ‚Äî data engineers, analysts, scientists, developers, and business decision-makers. Every feature, every integration is designed to help someone do their job better.
  2. Modern Lakehouse Architecture: BDC acts as the unified data lake for SAP ‚Äî but it plays well with others. It integrates with platforms like Databricks, Azure, and BigQuery using open file formats like Parquet and protocols like Delta Lake.
  3. The Data product: One of the most exciting innovations is the data product ‚Äî a combination of metadata, data, and an API wrapper that allows zero-copy, governed sharing. These aren‚Äôt just generic objects ‚Äî they‚Äôre tied to your SAP instance, with your extensions, running on the cloud provider of your choice.
  4. End to End Tooling : BDC brings together tools like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, BW/4HANA PCE, and SAP Databricks ‚Äî making it possible to go from raw data to models to intelligent apps in a seamless flow.
  5. Open Data Exchange: This isn‚Äôt about locking you in. It‚Äôs about sharing and subscribing to data across SAP and non-SAP systems ‚Äî using open standards, securely and efficiently.

Five Guiding Principles of SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP BDC as the Fabric of Enterprise Data

Another key theme that stood out was SAP BDC‚Äôs role in a data fabric architecture.

‚ÄúA data fabric connects SAP and non-SAP data with semantics, metadata, observability, and governance ‚Äî without needing to centralize it all.‚Äù ‚Äì Prakash Nanduri

Instead of duplicating data across lakes and warehouses, BDC helps you leave the data where it is ‚Äî while making it usable across all your use cases. With BDC as a data fabric, you get:

  • Federated access to SAP and third-party data
  • Built-in semantics and metadata to make data understandable
  • Lineage and observability for trust and traceability
  • Real-time APIs to power apps, AI, and analytics

This model is key for large enterprises that need agility without sacrificing control ‚Äî and BDC makes that a reality.

Continue our path towards a Business Data Fabric

Rapid Innovation, Tangible Progress

Here‚Äôs what really stood out: BDC isn‚Äôt just an idea on paper. It‚Äôs live. It's growing. And it's delivering.

  • Over 130 SAP-generated data products are already available. We expect 470+ by end of 2025.
  • New intelligent applications like People Intelligence are live and built entirely on BDC.
  • Databricks integration means data scientists can use Jupiter notebooks with live SAP data, securely and efficiently.
  • BW modernization now allows BW data to be accessed in Parquet format ‚Äî unlocking new value without heavy lifting.

These aren‚Äôt future promises. They‚Äôre things you and I can start working with today.

Listening to the Community: What You Told Us

Another highlight for me was when Timo Elliott walked us through the live feedback from our community. What‚Äôs holding organizations back from using their data more effectively?

  • Complexity
  • Lack of context
  • Poor quality and integration
  • Difficulty accessing the right data

And what do people want from SAP and other vendors? 

  • Less marketing, more clarity
  • Tools that are hands-on and simple
  • Open standards and real-world use cases
  • Broader AI accessibility

Timo said something that stayed with me:  ‚ÄúData quality is never just a technical issue ‚Äî it‚Äôs often a symptom of broken business processes.‚Äù.  That‚Äôs a truth we need to keep repeating. Tools can only go so far if we don‚Äôt also look at the organizational habits behind them.

The Questions Everyone‚Äôs Asking

Gaurish Dessai jumped in to answer the three most frequently asked questions throughout the series ‚Äî and he answered them with precision:

  • Where can I find SAP‚Äôs data products?
    ‚Üí Check out the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. There‚Äôs now a dedicated section for data products.
  • What intelligent applications are available or coming?
    ‚Üí Already live: Working Capital, People Intelligence
    ‚Üí Coming soon: Finance, Customer, Supply Chain, and Spend Intelligence
  • Where can I see what‚Äôs being launched next?
    ‚Üí Visit the SAP Product Roadmap Explorer and search for ‚ÄúBusiness Data Cloud‚Äù

If you haven‚Äôt bookmarked those resources, I highly recommend you do.

What‚Äôs Coming Next?

Ralph Richter gave us a look at the future ‚Äî and it‚Äôs full of opportunities:

  • Free trials and BDC assessments are now available
  • Community events are expanding, including: 
    • SAP + IBM Enterprise Architecture Dialog ‚Äì Sept 8, London
    • SAP Enterprise Architecture Summit ‚Äì Oct 7‚Äì9, Berlin
    • SAP Multidimensional Architect Program ‚Äì Oct, San Ramon

These aren‚Äôt just events ‚Äî they‚Äôre collaborative experiences focused on the human and technical skills architects need to thrive now.

One Big Takeaway

As we closed the session, Paul asked the panel: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your one big takeaway?‚Äù

  • Gaurish Dessai: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never been a better time to be a Data Architect.‚Äù
  • Timo Elliott: ‚ÄúBDC is the foundation ‚Äî not just for data, but for everything we do with AI in the future.‚Äù
  • Paul Kurchina: ‚ÄúThis is a journey we‚Äôre on ‚Äî and we‚Äôre on it together, as a community.‚Äù

My Reflection

As an Enterprise Architect at SAP, this series has been a meaningful checkpoint in how we think about the future of data architecture. What stood out to me is that SAP Business Data Cloud isn‚Äôt just a new platform ‚Äî it represents a strategic shift in how we deliver business value through data.  The move toward data products ‚Äî harmonized, reusable, and ready for AI ‚Äî changes the game. It challenges us to stop thinking in silos and start thinking in ecosystems. It's not just about integration anymore; it‚Äôs about orchestration across people, platforms, and processes.

BDC gives us the architectural clarity to do what we‚Äôve always aimed for: simplify complexity, scale intelligence, and empower business users ‚Äî without compromising governance or trust. In many ways, this moment reminds us that architecture is no longer just about systems ‚Äî it's about enabling possibility.

entry.title: Influencing posting price at GR with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE
entry.content:
Hi there.

We are trying to influence the material price when posting a goods receipt with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE.
Therefore we are using the field AMOUNT_LC of structure GOODSMVT_ITEM. 

According to it"s documentation (BAPI_EXBWR) this field can be used for

"The value of the movement is calculated automatically by the system. However, it is possible to enter an amount manually if the item is to be valuated at a different price."

But is seems this documentation is not accurate, since when we are setting a different price in structure GOODSMVT_ITEM-AMOUNT_LC only MSEG-EXBWR gets updated with this, but not MSEG-DMBTR which is the base for the valuation of the material document. 
Is it really possible to influence the price with field AMOUNT_LC in BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE?
Maybe someone made the same experience and has a solution for it
Somehow the documentation of  BAPI_EXBWR seems to be misleading.

Thank you very much in advance
Best regards

Heinz

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-08-04?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

It‚Äôs great to be back with another round of exciting updates. August brought some fresh changes to the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model, and I‚Äôm here to walk you through what‚Äôs new.

Let‚Äôs jump right in and explore the highlights!

Environment screen

For users accessing the User Guide or reporting an incident, Built-in Support from SAP is now available directly in your tenants.
With this update, not only can you still access the User Guide and report incidents, but you can now also navigate to the SAP Community directly from the application.
As a result, the previous Help option will be replaced by this new built-in support experience.

For more information, please visit Integrated Support Experience: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model with SAP Built-in Support.

Modeling screen

Good news for modelers!
To improve efficiency, the Activate button on the Modeling screen now comes with extended functionality - it will first save any changes made to the modeling configuration and then proceed with activation, just like how it works in SAP PaPM On-Premise version.

Report Management screen | Chat with AI copilot - Joule

A new feature in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model has been enhanced in the Settings and Report Management screens to enable AI-powered insights via Joule.
To start using Joule in the application, some initial setup is required in SAP BTP. These steps are described in the SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.
After the setup, simply go to the Settings screen and, under the new ‚ÄúJoule AI Settings‚Äù section, select your SAP AI Core destination and choose the AI model you want to use.

Once configured, Joule becomes available in the Report Management screen, allowing users to ask questions about the report and receive instant answers from AI.

More details on how to configure Joule in SAP BTP and how to use it later in the Report Management screen can be found in the SAP PaPM Cloud blog post SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Enhancing Report Management with the power of generative AI copilot ‚Äì Joule, or by visiting our Application Help portal SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.

Administration | Settings screen

Administrators and modelers can now add additional mapping fields to their Remote Function Adapters using the new RFA template. To do this, simply navigate to the Settings screen and select Customize RFA Template.

For more information, please refer to Application Help portal Modeling Settings or visit SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature.

Administration | Content Management screen

To help administrators avoid accidental overwrites, the Content Management screen now displays a warning message when the ‚ÄúOverwrite‚Äù option is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù, alerting users that changes from the current environment version will be lost.

That wraps up this month‚Äôs round of updates! Hopefully, these new features make your day-to-day work a little smoother.
Stay tuned, stay engaged, and see you in the next one!

entry.title: Stock not transferred from ROD storage location after SMQ2 error solving
entry.content:
We have a SAP S4 set-up with embedded EWM. We have a ROD (received on dock) storage location and an AFS (available for sale) storage location in our EWM. So as long as the putaway warehouse tasks aren't confirmed, the stock remains in the ROD storage location. When we then confirm the warehouse tasks, the stock is moved with a transfer order and movement type 411 automatically to storage location AFS. 

When something goes wrong on the inbound flow, and we need to reprocess an inbound delivery that got stuck in the SMQ2 error queue (note that we solve the error queue, and not just save the LUW to SMQ3!), we experience that our automatic 411 transfer from the ROD storage location to the AFS storage location does not happen anymore. Probably because the warehouse tasks that trigger it, had already been confirmed. 

Does anyone have any experience in how to solve this?

entry.title: Re: How to Check Storefront's IPs and IP Range
entry.content:
Dear Customer,
I hope you are doing well.

To find the public IP address for your SAP Commerce Cloud environment, follow these steps:

  1. Open the Cloud Portal home page.
  2. Navigate to the environment details page for your desired Commerce Cloud environment.
  3. Click on an endpoint's name to access the "Edit Endpoint" page.
  4. The public IP address is shown in the web proxy field in the General Information section.

Please note that the public IP is consistent across all public endpoints within the environment.

Kind regards,
B√°rbara
SAP Support

Hello,

entry.title: Re: external definition imported from sap pi is causing i...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information solves your issue? (GenAI was used to help generate this content)

When migrating SAP PI interfaces to SAP CPI, issues such as missing nodes in message mappings can occur, often due to prefix mismatches in external definitions. Here are some steps you can take to address these issues:

  1. Review External Definitions: Ensure that the external definitions used in SAP PI are correctly imported into SAP CPI. Check if the prefixes used in the XML schema definitions are consistent.

  2. Adjust Prefixes: If prefixes are causing nodes to be missing, you may need to manually adjust the prefixes in the external definitions within SAP CPI to match those used in SAP PI.

  3. Use Developer Extensibility: Developer Extensibility of Incoming Format Mappings SAP S/4HANA Cloud offers developer extensibility options that can be used to preprocess or postprocess input and output files. This can help in adjusting structures as needed.

Developer Extensibility of Incoming Format Mappings

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: What value pick for the tag <PmtInfId> in DME XML fil...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information solves your issue? (GenAI was used to help generate this content)

In the SAP pre-delivered payment file for Switzerland, the <PmtInfId> tag in the DME payment file (XML) is derived from the reference number used in the payment process. It appears that the system adds a specific value, such as 101, to the reference number to generate the <PmtInfId>.

For example, if the reference number is 1000000250, the <PmtInfId> in the payment file becomes 1000000351. This transformation is likely part of the standard configuration or logic applied by SAP to ensure uniqueness or compliance with specific requirements.

Unfortunately, the exact logic or configuration details for this transformation are not readily visible in the ‚ÄòManage Automatic Payments‚Äô app. It might be necessary to check the configuration settings or consult SAP documentation specific to Switzerland‚Äôs payment formats for further insights.

If you need to adjust or understand this behavior further, you might consider exploring the configuration settings related to payment formats.

Switzerland: Configuring Payment Medium Formats

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Influencing posting price at GR with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CR...
entry.content:
The field AMOUNT_LC in GOODSMVT_ITEM does update MSEG-EXBWR, which is the externally entered amount. However, MSEG-DMBTR (the actual valuation amount) is not influenced by AMOUNT_LC unless specific conditions are met. So yes, you can enter a manual amount, but it won‚Äôt override the valuation price unless SAP is explicitly configured to accept it; which it typically is not in standard scenarios.

Why MSEG-DMBTR is not updated is because, SAP uses standard valuation logic based on:
- Material master price (standard or moving average)
- Purchase order price
- Valuation class and account determination
Even if you pass a custom amount via AMOUNT_LC, the system still calculates DMBTR using its internal valuation rules unless
- You use a non-valuated movement type
- You post to a non-valuated stock
- You implement a custom enhancement or BAdI

Possible Workarounds are
1. Custom Movement Type
- Create a Z-movement type that allows manual valuation
- Set valuation indicator to allow external price input
2. Enhancement via BAdI
- Use MB_DOCUMENT_BADI or MB_MIGO_BADI to override valuation logic
- Inject custom logic to set DMBTR based on EXBWR
3. Use Non-Valuated GR
- If business allows, post GR as non-valuated and handle valuation separately

entry.title: SAP Concur Fusion Exchange EMEA in London.
entry.content:
‚ÄÉ

On June 12th I attended Fusion Exchange EMEA in London.

I was hosting a booth with a colleague to represent our area of expertise which is SAP Integration with Concur Solutions also knows as ICS.  More about that further down.

Fusion Exchange EMEA is a one-day, complimentary event to exchange knowledge with your peers managing travel, expense and invoice, our partners, and SAP Concur experts. It is an event to showcase the latest industry trends, value-adding solutions for business organisations, and how to maximise your SAP Concur investment.

The agenda offered immersive educational sessions, ample opportunity to network, and personalised experiences.

 

SAP Concur Keynote

Since, I was manning the ICS booth I did not get so much time to explore the various sessions, but I was able to attend the SAP Concur keynote.  They keynote kicked off at 09:15 for an hour.  It was inspiring to see the SAP Concur leaders as they unveiled the next era of travel and expense management.

They shared the vision shaping our industries future and spoke about the latest innovations. I also heard inspiring insights and real-world stories from customers. In my daily work I never get to see and hear how it truly is ‚Äúon the other side‚Äù face to face.  I must admit I was very impressed.  It is also nice to see and hear what is happening within the company outside of my area of expertise. It made me realise how big the Travel and Expense industry is and how many companies rely on us in SAP Concur for their companies to run their T&E departments efficiently day to day.

Throughout the day there were also 11 Breakout sessions, and 6 Micro Forums open to all.  As I wrote above I did not have much time to attend many sessions but I did manage to slip away twice.   

Expense Breakout Session - A closer look at managing expenses: recent innovations and peer use cases

Here I saw Control spend before it happens, with Concur Request, ExpenseIT on the Web, Microsoft Teams Integration, Microsoft Outlook Integration - Attendee adding, receipt digitalization and much more.  For me and I‚Äôm sure many others it was the AI part I really wanted to hear about.  I was delighted when a slide popped up with the header titled AI at every step of the process.   This part focused on creating an intelligent front-loaded user experience, where you can optimise compliance and user experience at every step with no compromise.  The industry future is changing faster than I thought.

 

Breakout Session - Revolutionising compliance through innovation and technology

I have been in the financial software industry for almost 30 years both as a developer and consultant. Compliance has always been a topic that interests me and a topic i feel only in the last 5 ‚Äì 6 years is only getting the attention it deserves.  I can remember many occasions when i was a payroll developer writing ABAP reports to fix customer own EOY reconciliations which were most regulatory and not policy for tax and auditing. That feels like a lifetime ago now.

My take aways were where the current approaches fall short because of decentralized controls, lack of real time monitoring and gaps in trainings etc.

AI will also play a big a role to help improve spend compliance (Behaviour) and efficiency (usability).   AI for example can help with instant trip estimation, simple receipt capture and expense creation with automatic hotel automatization.

An interesting slide I saw had the following statistic.  For Hotel Itemization there can be up to 93% reduction in time spent on approvals for rejected expense reports.  That made me smile.

 

SAP Integration with Concur Solutions Booth

My colleague Ryma and I manned the booth for the day. We had over 35 visitors.  I always enjoy meeting customers and this was no exception.   Throughout the day we answered many prospective and existing customer questions on a broad range of topics ranging from setup to posting and how to fulfill business requirements.    

A further plus was meeting colleagues such as Angela, Paul and Rahul who I only ever really see on a screen.   It was a pleasure to meet you and have some laughs.

Lastly a special thank you to Ryma. It was a joy to represent our product and team with you.

If for some reason you are reading this blog and would like to know more about SAP Financial Integration with Concur Solutions then simply send an e-mail to sapconcurintegration@sap.com with the word subscribe in the subject of the e-mail.

Then you will be invited to our Work Zone Workspaces (aka SAP Jam pages).

I will sign off with the following.   It‚Äôs no fun running around London trying to find a Labubu doll while running for a flight.  If you know.. you know üòä !

Bye for now.

Damien Fleming.

entry.title: Re: Condition Types in Purchase Orders and Contracts (Hea...
entry.content:
Hello @Shubham120798 

Only a predefined set of condition types is available‚Äîcustom types or pricing routines are not allowed in S4HANA Publi cloud. These are used during pricing in sales documents like sales orders, contracts, and quotations.
  Common Standard Condition Types

Item-Level:

  • PPR0 ‚Äì Base price
  • MWST ‚Äì Output tax (statistical)
  • FRA1 ‚Äì Freight charges
  • VPRS ‚Äì Cost (statistical)

Header-Level (manual only):

  • HB00 ‚Äì Absolute discount
  • RB00 ‚Äì Percentage discount
  • HD00 ‚Äì Freight charge
  • RO00 ‚Äì Manual adjustment

You can maintain condition records using the Manage Prices ‚Äì Sales app.
How to Check in Your System

  • SSCUI 100297 ‚Äì View allowed condition types (read-only)
  • SSCUI 100505 ‚Äì View pricing procedure setup
  • CDS View I_SalesOrderItemPricingElement ‚Äì Analyze applied condition types in orders

Configuring Pricing Using the Implementation Activities App 

Let me know if helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Handling inventory updates from EWM to S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in 7L1 integration scenario
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I‚Äôm working on an integration between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP EWM on Private Cloud, using the 7L1 scope item and communication scenario SAP_COM_0A58.

The standard delivery-based processes (inbound, outbound, stock transport orders) are working fine. However, we‚Äôre facing challenges with warehouse-driven updates that need to be reflected back in ERP.

Examples of limitations we‚Äôre encountering:

  • Pick Denial
    When picking in EWM is partially denied, the reduced quantity is not reflected in the outbound delivery in ERP. This can cause inconsistencies in fulfillment and invoicing.

  • Physical Inventory Differences
    When a cycle count is processed and differences are posted in EWM, the updated stock quantity is not synchronized back to ERP. The ERP stock remains unchanged.

  • Ready for Shipping status
    When the goods are packed or staged in EWM, the ‚ÄúReady for Shipping‚Äù status is not updated in the ERP delivery.

According to SAP Note 3629180:

SAP clearly states these processes are not supported in the standard 7L1 integration.

I‚Äôve come across several discussions and documents suggesting that these types of updates could be solved via custom SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) flows for example, by pushing events from EWM and updating ERP via exposed APIs.

My question:

  • Is CPI indeed the recommended workaround for synchronizing EWM status and inventory changes to ERP in this scenario?

  • Are there any best practices, alternative approaches, or roadmap items to cover these types of back-synchronizations?

  • How are other customers or partners solving this in mixed EWM decentralized + S/4HANA Public Cloud environments?

Any guidance or insights would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to use MF60 for creating WM transfer r...
entry.content:
Normally, MF60 is used to transfer components from a replenishment location (e.g., warehouse) to an issue location (e.g., production line). If both are the same, SAP may not generate a transfer requirement because it sees no need to move stock.

How to make it work is to use Movement Type 311. Even if the locations are the same, MF60 can still create a reservation using movement type 311 (stock transfer within the same plant). This helps in tracking staging activity even if no physical movement occurs.
In customizing, ensure that Pull List Control is set up to allow staging even when locations match. You may need to tweak the logic to force a reservation for visibility.
- In MF60, after selecting the production order, go to Replenishment Elements ‚Üí Replenishment Proposals, manually enter the same location for both issue and replenishment. SAP will still generate a staging document if the system sees a shortfall.
Check the box for ‚ÄúRound up replenishment proposals‚Äù. Leave Selection Horizon blank to include all requirements. This ensures the system doesn‚Äôt skip staging due to timing filters

By doing so, what you will achieve is
- A reservation document (visible in MB25) showing movement type 311
- Components staged ‚Äúvirtually‚Äù for production tracking
- Better visibility and control over material availability, even without physical movement

entry.title: SAP BTP - An Executive Introduction
entry.content:
@timoelliott is an innovation evangelist with SAP.  In this executive overview of SAP Business Technology Platform, Timo introduces the value of SAP BTP, its solutions, differentiators, key customer references and where to learn more. You can watch the original video here .

You may have noticed there's a lot of chaos in the modern world. Change seems to be changing faster, from pandemics that turn the world upside down to big, unexpected tariff changes that disrupt the world's supply chains overnight. And since everything relies on technology these days, reacting quickly to market changes means changing your computer systems. And that's not always as easy as it should be.

I'm sure you've seen this quote before: "Since the dawn of time, the key to survival has always been the ability to change." And yet, more than 80% of companies responding to a recent survey from McKinsey said they did not feel well-prepared to deal with rising volatility.

What are organizations looking to achieve? Well, in order to deal with faster change, we need to transform transformation ‚Äî accelerate our ability to innovate. In conversations with you, our customers, we find three key themes. First, companies are looking to better connect and coordinate their teams across internal silos so the company can act as one. Second, they're looking to take advantage of AI and automation to be able to adjust back-end systems faster than is possible when everything is done manually. Third, everyone wants to explore new business models: selling connected services rather than just products, or moving to subscription pricing, or developing more customized services, and so on.

So while it's difficult to create a formal ROI case for business agility, the reality is it makes the difference between surviving and thriving. The ability to change faster than the competition is one of THE biggest and most powerful differentiators you can have in your industry.

But you don't need me to tell you that change is hard. You probably have lots of disparate, disconnected systems that have grown up over the years, and they all talk different languages. Maintenance probably takes up a big chunk of your time and resources. Making changes means wading into custom code and integrations and involves a lot of costs and above all, risk. These are, after all, the systems that keep your business running. And it can be difficult finding the people with the right skills to solve today's technology challenges. And the data backs this up.

70% of CIOs say their current systems lack the agility to scale and integrate with modern technologies like AI. 80% of CIOs cite data quality and semantic challenges as their biggest obstacles to AI success. And 45% of businesses operating on legacy systems are less likely to adopt enterprise-wide AI due to technology limitations.

We all know that business transformation isn't about technology, but it certainly relies heavily on it. So the CIO has a critical role helping shepherd the competing demands from different areas of the business while maintaining a coherent technology strategy and governance. At SAP, our Business Suite vision aims to enable CIOs as transformational chief innovation officers rather than just chief infrastructure officers. Where IT is a strategic partner for the organization, and goes beyond IT management to drive transformation: aligning technology with the business goals.

SAP Business Technology Platform is what we use as the foundation for SAP's own innovations, and we have over 150 different applications running on the platform. But of course, we also make it available to you and our vast ecosystem of partners to help all areas of the business succeed, in partnership with the CIO. The platform is most often used by IT departments, but it's all about creating better business outcomes.

So what is SAP BTP? Well, it's a multi-cloud platform-as-a-service to unlock the full potential of your business. Optimized to work with SAP solutions, it's a unified platform of best of breed technologies to extend and integrate business applications and to infuse artificial intelligence and context-aware business data into everything you do.

We know that there are lots of different development environments out there, so when and why might SAP BTP be the right solution for your business needs? First, we've been in the business of business processes for decades. SAP BTP has out-of-the-box support to connect your processes and applications to just about any other system and application on the planet. Second, it's built for business. When you're designing something to extend your existing business applications and processes, there's no point reinventing the wheel. You can just quickly and easily leverage all the user object to security information that's already in your system. Third, we've been building AI into our applications for years, and while it's easy to do quick and powerful proof of concept projects with the latest gen AI technology, all the analyst research research shows that the vast majority of AI projects fail to go into production or add business value. We have deep expertise in helping our customers build mission-critical systems. We built robust assembly lines to integrate relevant, reliable and responsible business AI into all of our applications and we provide the same tested, production-ready tools to you. And finally, studies have proved that BTP adds value to other SAP Business Suite applications with a strong return on investment when BTP is deployed together with applications like SAP Cloud ERP, Successfactors, Ariba, and Finance.

SAP BTP is available globally with 42 data centers worldwide. It's helped over 33,000 customers achieve measurable impact across all industries and lines of business. Over 10,000 pre-built best practice artifacts speed up your time to value with pre-implemented workflows, and with a growing ecosystem of 3,200 partners that have built industry and line of business solutions on top of the platform, you're likely to find out-of-the-box solutions for your particular needs. And SAP BTP is recognized by leading analyst firms as a best in class vendor, leading in numerous technology categories.

Let's dive into the real content. SAP BTP covers five major solution areas: integration, application development and automation, artificial intelligence, data and analytics, and platform foundation. Let's look at each of these key areas in a bit more detail.

 

First, integration. Integration is one of the most time consuming and painful parts of any innovation project today. Organizations typically juggle multiple integration solutions, creating complexity, which in turn leads to longer projects and disjointed systems that continue to jeopardize business resiliency. So how does Integration Suite help with these challenges? SAP Integration Suite is a modern, scalable, and secure integration platform-as-a-service, empowering businesses to integrate all applications, systems and data across all landscapes, with one solution offering comprehensive capabilities to accelerate productivity and ensure reliable connectivity. Thousands of pre-built content allow you to deploy faster and more easily, greatly increasing your time to value. There are over 3,900 built-in integrations, over 4,000 ready-to-use integration APIs for faster connectivity, and Gartner recently rated SAP Integration Suite a market leader for the fifth consecutive year running.

Harrods, the iconic luxury department store first opened its doors in Knightsbridge, London, in 1849. To support its digital transformation and strategic shift to a modern e-commerce platform, the company selected SAP Integration Suite to connect both cloud and on-premise technologies, internal and third-party systems across multiple protocols, all within a single platform. The result was a 40% reduction in total costs and 30% shorter process times, and with the standardization, Harrods can now more easily engage with partners and expand its global presence to meet increased customer demand in new markets, including China and the Middle East.

 

The second solution area for BTP is application development and automation. Building and extending enterprise applications with the wrong tools can be difficult and expensive, and deep collaboration between the business is always required for a successful outcome. Extensions need to be securely integrated with your core business systems. This is where SAP Build comes in. It provides tools for all levels of expertise, from professional developers to power users who only want to drag and drop to create applications. Analyst studies show that SAP Build drives 3X developer productivity and you can start coding with natural language: AI now understands your business, technology, data, and context. Deep integration with SAP and non-SAP applications provides the fastest way to create an application, automated process, or business site in a clean-core way. There are already over 17,000 customers using SAP Build solutions.

For example, in order to engage with the Gen Z audience, engineering multinational ThyssenKrupp has launched a new social media recruiting channel. The core of this approach is an app built in-house using the low-code SAP Build Apps development environment, helping citizen developers create and manage workflows for different HR applications. The intuitive app empowers personnel in more than 100 different HR departments to quickly create application flows for different job types, without needing any coding skills. This helps ThyssenKrupp respond to changing recruitment requirements in an agile and efficient way.

 

The third solution area of BTP we‚Äôll look at is artificial intelligence. We could obviously talk for hours about AI, but the key challenges are that there are not enough resources to adopt AI as quickly as everybody would like across the enterprise, that the business data required for scaling AI is typically very fragmented, and that large language models are not always accurate and trustworthy. The AI in BTP is designed for trust. We have built a production-ready AI orchestration platform to allow you to embed AI into all of your business processes with confidence. We use that platform to provide over 230 individual use cases across the SAP Business Suite, and we're training specific AI models on high-quality, industry-specific tabular business data, and leveraging our deep process knowledge. In addition, AI is built into all of the BTP solutions such as Joule studio and Build for developers.

 

For example, when Germany was hit by a sharp rise in energy prices recently because of getting cut off from Russian gas, the City of Hamburg used SAP AI services and other solutions to efficiently process almost 100,000 applications relating to aid. The financial aid platform was launched in only two weeks, and allowed the city of Hamburg to start distributing ‚Ç¨2.5 billion in special fund to public and private cultural institutions. It's an intuitive, self-service platform that leverages generative AI to support a digitalized application process for cultural events, including the initial request, the validity checks, objection handling and payment. BTP and AI greatly sped up the processing of the applications far quicker than would otherwise been possible.

 

The fourth solution area of BTP is data and analytics provided by Business Data Cloud. Business users need data for all of their analytics planning needs in real time, with full business context. At SAP, we believe this requires integration between all data platforms and business applications with data products based on a one-domain model for consistency‚Äîand connecting insights and business decisions is now more important than ever in the new AI era. SAP Business Data Cloud accelerates the process of turning data into decisions with ‚Äúinsights-as-a-service‚Äù: pre-built, out-of-the-box analytic apps to help you make smart decisions faster. They leverage fully-managed, curated data products across all lines of business, providing advanced analytics and planning apps across core enterprise, analytics, finance, people, and much more. It unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third party data using Delta Sharing and Data Federation to connect all your data with zero copies. And you can easily create AI apps and AI models trained on your business data, using for example, SAP Databricks. That semantically-rich data helps ground your AI to ensure accurate outcomes with Joule Copilot to accelerate productivity and automate complex business processes. Data and AI governance is more important than ever. With SAP Business Data Cloud, business users get clean ownership with minimal engineering overhead.

Leading global airline group Lufthansa sought to harmonize critical data from siloed systems across its subsidiaries by integrating the SAP Datasphere solution, now part of Business Data Cloud, with a partner solution on SAP Business Technology platform. It federated SAP and third-party data while preserving key metadata, making it available for analytics and business intelligence. They took data from over 20 different cloud and on-premise systems scattered across various subsidiaries, and brought it all together for a consolidated 360 degree view of the organization's financial performance, with greater spend transparency across various source systems, helping deliver better margins and resilience.

 

The fifth and final key solution area of BTP is the platform foundation. With threat vectors from many sources, companies are prioritizing security at the highest levels. At the same time, IT leaders need to streamline operations while providing the application scalability needed for the business to stay competitive. SAP BTP Platform Foundation provides the secure, scalable and reliable foundation you need to innovate with confidence across your business suite. It provides all the critical functionality to deliver production-ready innovation environments. It provides efficient application lifecycle management; streamlined development with integrated access controls to ensure global identity security and compliance; a global platform abstraction layer for integration across all core hyperscalers provides flexibility for the future; secure connectivity is provided for all applications and data across hybrid environments; and there are automated management and performance tools to streamline administration and operations.

Mahindra Group has been an SAP customer for 25 years, enabling the conglomerate to grow and continuously innovate. And now they're leaping into a cloud-based digital future. With the RISE with SAP solution and SAP Business Technology Platform was a logical next step for the company. The BTP foundation capabilities allowed them to accelerate the development of their new mission-critical workloads, optimize IT costs with a scalable and on-demand cloud infrastructure, and meet sustainability goals by reducing carbon emissions from IT systems. They automated over 250 processes and gave business users more self-service functionality, saving over 1,000 workdays, giving them more time to work on more strategic tasks. And they were even able to decommission 194 different servers, leading to a much lower IT carbon footprint.

In summary, we've looked at the five key areas of BTP: integration, application development and automation artificial intelligence, data and analytics, and platform foundation. SAP BTP empowers you to integrate and extend business applications faster; connects systems and processes across the enterprise; and personalize applications for your business needs. Create business relevant apps with all your data: leverage SAP Business Data Cloud to build smarter applications and develop reliable AI solutions grounded in full business context. Innovate and accelerate with artificial intelligence: boost developer productivity with generative AI, securely infuse AI models into applications, and develop reliable AI solutions at scale.

 

To close, I'd like to highlight a recent study from IDC that summarizes the value of BTP for SAP customers. Customers in the study, on average, found a three-year return on investment of over 500% and eight months to pay back their investment, with significantly higher productivity for their development teams.

To find out more, please visit sap.com/btp to learn everything you need about SAP‚Äôs technology platform for all applications. You can get started for free‚Äîtry before you buy to test drive the power of SAP BTP. And please join our growing community of SAP technology users to meet others facing the same business challenges and opportunities that you are, and get your SAP BTP questions asked and answered. I wish you the very best of luck with your projects. Thank you very much for your time and goodbye!

entry.title: Re: How to add fields to LSMW Standard Batch Input
entry.content:
Hi @ABS21 

Thanks for your question.

Since you're using LSMW with standard batch input (Object 0480 / Method 0000) for Functional Location Task Lists (IA11) and the two new fields appear in the IA11 UI but not in the IBIPTLOP structure, it indicates that these fields are not supported by the standard batch input program (RCPTRA01).

This is my suggestion on how to Proceed:
Create a custom LSMW recording for transaction IA01/IA11, which captures screen fields including those not supported by batch input structures. However, this can be brittle if screens vary by user or SAP version.

Unfortunately, for IA11 there is no standard BAPI for uploading Functional Location Task Lists. So this might not be feasible unless you build a custom program.


If the fields are part of custom enhancements (e.g. appended to CI structures), you may need to use a custom BDC or enhance the batch input structure (though SAP doesn‚Äôt recommend modifying standard structures).

Alternatively, If the fields belong to custom append structures, you might consider using a custom Z-program or eCATT that directly updates the required tables.

I hope this gives more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Onboarding - Know your key people
entry.content:
Hi @tomaszgondek 

Thank you for your question.

You're correct that in Onboarding 1.0, it was possible to customize the ‚ÄúKnow Your Key People‚Äù section to display specific roles through configuration. However, in Onboarding 2.0, this section is more restricted and primarily auto populated with the manager‚Äôs details by default.

As of today, there is no standard configuration available in Onboarding 2.0 to force the display of additional people e.g., someone from IT alongside the manager unless they are added via recommendation or assignment.

That said, I suggest you do the following:

  • Create a custom MDF object or business rule to auto-assign recommended people during onboarding.
  • Use Process Variant Manager to guide the flow based on criteria.
  • Add a custom UI tile or card in the New Hire Dashboard via People Profile extensions (Please note, this is more of a workaround than native functionality).

If SAP releases a new feature or enhancement allowing more flexibility in this area, it would be documented in the What's New Viewer or release notes.

I hope this gives more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Stock not transferred from ROD storage location after...
entry.content:
Hi @CharlotteH 

Thanks for your detailed explanation of the scenario.

Your observation is correct. The automatic 411 movement from ROD to AFS which normally triggers upon putaway warehouse task confirmation does not happen again after the delivery is reprocessed in SMQ2, particularly if the warehouse tasks had already been confirmed.

The reason is as follows:

The designated trigger for the 411 movement is tightly linked to the initial warehouse task confirmation event.

Once that confirmation has occurred, reprocessing the inbound queue (LUW in SMQ2) doesn‚Äôt retrigger the stock movement logic, as the system considers the physical stock movement already completed.

Here is my suggestion on how to resolve it:

  • If the stock is still technically in the ROD location but not reflected in AFS, you can manually post the 411 movement (ROD ‚Üí AFS) via MB1B or MIGO using movement type 411/E (if relevant for your scenario).
  • You may also use the Adjust Stock Posting transaction /SCWM/ADGI to realign stock between EWM and MM if you have inconsistencies after queue reprocessing.
  • If this happens frequently, consider implementing a BAdI or enhancement to monitor the state of warehouse tasks and trigger the required movement or follow-up delivery update logic post-SMQ2 reprocessing.

 

Please note, there may be a relevant SAP Note or fix depending on your release version. If this behaviour is not consistent with expected design, I‚Äôd suggest raising an incident under component SCM-EWM-IF-ERP to confirm with SAP if it can be handled more gracefully in newer releases or via a standard BADI.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Recording Additional Costs on a Purchase Order in SAP...
entry.content:
Hello @MariaIsabelPaz 

Thanks for sharing your requirement.

Yes, you can indeed post a second supplier invoice (Supplier B) for additional costs like freight or customs and associate it with the same purchase order (even if Supplier‚ÄØA has already invoiced the goods).

This is how you can achieve that:

Use the Fiori app to post the additional invoice. You can reference the same PO and assign the costs as separate invoice line items tied to service or unplanned items.


If your PO includes a condition item for freight or other costs, you can add related invoice amounts against those PO items (ensuring they don‚Äôt affect stock quantity). Otherwise, you can still enter costs as separate line items manually.

If you‚Äôre managing landed costs across multiple suppliers, SAP supports planned delivery costs in public cloud, where Supplier‚ÄØB invoices (e.g. customs) are recorded and posted to separate liability or cost accounts.

If you use Transportation Management (TM), you can post unplanned freight charges in the invoice and refer to a freight order or freight booking. These can be invoiced separately and tied back to the source PO.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

See useful links below:

Create Purchase Order Centrally

Create Supplier Invoices - Advanced

Invoicing Freight Orders

entry.title: Re: remove comma from the last line on output file in the...
entry.content:
Hi @user116 

Thank you for your question.

In SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center, when generating an EDI/Stacked Delimited file, there isn‚Äôt a direct UI option to suppress the trailing comma on the last line.

However, here is my suggestion:

  • Create a calculated field that appends a delimiter (comma) only if it is not the last record. This typically requires adding a flag using Integration Centre‚Äôs sequencing or row numbering logic, which can be complex for stacked formats.
  • If you‚Äôre exporting the file to an SFTP or middleware, consider adding a post-processing script that removes the trailing comma from the last line before sending it downstream.
  • Since the current Integration Center has limited formatting controls for EDI/stacked files, you may also consider submitting an enhancement request via the SAP Influence Portal.

Unfortunately, there is currently no built-in toggle in Integration Center to remove the last comma for stacked EDI output.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Automatic and Manual Payment Errors in SAP S/4HANA Cl...
entry.content:
Hello @MariaIsabelPaz 

Thank you for your message.

Even though IBAN isn‚Äôt mandatory in Venezuela, the system still validates vendor bank data based on the assigned payment method. If required fields like bank key, account number, or account holder are missing or misaligned with the configuration for payment method T, the automatic payment run may fail.

Since you already followed KBA 3444334, I‚Äôd recommend double-checking:

  • That all mandatory bank fields are filled for the vendor.
  • That payment method T is properly configured for Venezuela.
  • That the bank account is correctly maintained in the Business Partner app.

If everything looks correct, the issue might stem from backend validation still expecting certain fields like IBAN. In that case, opening an SAP support ticket with your system details may help clarify the validation logic.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: User Type FW is Not Active in SAP?
entry.content:
User Type FW is Not Active Error 

When we try to create a reference user or copy an existing user using SU01 t-code in SAP then we face the error message: User Type FW is not active in SAP. 

This error comes when the user you are copying is of type FW (Workflow System User), and in your system, this user type is not yet activated or supported because the workflow configuration is incomplete. 

In my case, we faced this issue specifically with user type FW but in your case the user type may be different. So it‚Äôs important to first identify your user type. 

How to Check and Activate Missing User Types using USMM T-Code.

  1. First Run the T-code USMM in the SAP GUI. 
  2. Then Click on the User Types tab. 

 

       3. Select and activate the missing user type FW or any other that's required. 

       4. Save your changes. 

Now try to create or copy the reference user again. If the error persists feel free to reach out or comment below if I can help resolve your issue I definitely will!
